transcripts.text: Good afternoon, good evening, good morning, depending on where you are.  This is Catania Alvin speaking from London.  This, now the second, so that was the coup that's going on in America.  and here I've got, well I suppose you could call it in a way, the coup that happened when Edward Heath was Prime Minister and he took us into the EU.  and then over that period of time between then and now, maybe about Six years ago, five years ago, we actually completely lost our sovereignty by taking a further step.  And now, last year we had a referendum, last June we had a referendum, and 17 plus million people voted to leave Europe.  Here is Sir William Cash talking in the House of Parliament and reminding people of something very important.  Here we go.
The duty of this House is to surrender parliamentary government to government by parliament.
Yeah, and so this surrendering, this is one of, in part, the deal.  And he's saying, no.

And in fact, that is well established in our constitutional arrangements.  And furthermore, any attempt by shenanigans to attempt to rearrange the procedures to give private members bills an advantage over government business itself is reprehensible for that very good reason.  But anyway, I want really to turn to another question, which is...
of the control over laws

because I think it is very, very important for every member of this House to ask themselves whether they would be prepared to tell their constituents that under this Withdrawal Agreement that we would be expected, in fact we would be required by an Act of Parliament to surrender control over our laws under Article 4 of the Withdrawal
Agreement.  Can you imagine the electorate agreeing to that, to surrender our laws to those of the EU?
If people haven't had the time or perhaps the opportunity to read Article 4, may I suggest that they do so?  Because to do otherwise would be utterly and completely irresponsible.  Yes, of course.
If we don't have control of our laws, we don't have control of our country, is that not right?  absolutely right.

That is completely right and that is what we are actually here for.  We are not here just to voice our own opinions or to fragment into factions and then to impose views on other people by virtue of deals that are done across the floor of the House.

We are elected on manifesto commitments and we have an obligation to our constituents to make laws in their interests, not in ours.  I hope every parliamentarian hears him.  You are there, you, the ones that have been voted into parliament, to stand by the constitution and the laws of the land.

And therefore I would suggest that looking at Article 4 was extremely important indeed.  I accept that it is said that it would only be through the implementation period, but that in itself would put us at the mercy of our competitors, trade unionists, workers, I'm very grateful to my old friend.  I think it's actually worse than that, because it's not just the implementation period, it's the whole of the backstop, and that would potentially be unlimited, and the European Court of Justice, against our manifesto commitment, would therefore remain the supreme arbiter of our laws in that area.
And that could last for a very long time.
I'm so glad that my old friend has made that point because I was just about
to come on to it and I don't have to make that point myself because I'm

as much against the backstop as it is as I am against the Article 4 arrangements for the reasons that both of us agree about.  But the question we have to just grapple with is This Article 4 is across all the treaties, all the laws, all the legal positions that have been adopted by the Court of Justice over the last number of years, and it is inconceivable that this House would hollow itself out in such a manner as to preclude itself from being able to control them.  I'm chairman of the European Security Committee.  We get these regulations and directives, week in, week out.  And we've just had one last week, which is intended to aim at turning the veto, the unanimity rule regarding the making of national tax policy, into qualified majority voting.
Now if people really think that that is a minor matter, let them think again what effect that would have on their constituents.  Right.  I was just looking for Article 4, but my page won't come up.

What is further to the point is that our country would be, as I said in my intervention with the Chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster, will be reduced to an undemocratic subjugation to the decisions of 20 other member states.

undemocratic subjugation.  That's what they're trying to bring Britain into.  That's actually what we've been.  And that's why 17 million people voted against staying in the European Union.  They said, get out.  We want to exit Europe.  Because they were aware, to a degree, of the subjugation that Britain had been in, and that was very clear when Codex Elementarius was actually going on, and our natural health and various other things were slashed to bits and pieces.

And in fact, not only that, but as I've said just now, it would put us at the mercy of our competitors, in addition to which, in the backstop, it would also have the same effect with regard to the question of state aides.  I don't think that businesses who argued so strongly for this transitional period had any idea.  that under this withdrawal agreement, which emerged

from the Chequers deal, which itself was an overturning of the Withdrawal Act, which we passed in June 2018, which had been pre-planned long before that Act, long before that Act was put through Royal Assent, without any reference to the Cabinet, and in defiance of Cabinet responsibility, without any reference to cabinet, and in defiance of cabinet responsibility.  This would be the consequence.  So, the other thing is, if we don't control those laws, who will?  Exactly.

And if you look at a book, for example, a very important book by our former ambassador to Germany, Sir Paul Lever, he is called Berlin Rules, and he says unequivocally... that before decisions are taken by the European member states, or indeed by the Council of Ministers, they are cleared with Germany first.  He also says it is a German Europe.  He's not mincing his words.
I certainly give way.  Very, very interesting.
The utter irony of the situation.  He moans and complains and chip on the shoulder and grievance about Europe.

But the realities of Scotland and the United Kingdom is worse than everything he's seen at home.  We have a government in charge, a party in charge.  we've not voted for in 65 years.  The European Union is nothing as bad as what he's going on about here.
Well, that's a nonsense.  That's my first point.  Control over laws and Article 4 is so offensive.  It hollows out this house.  It hollows out our democracy.
And it actually is something which, on the basis of that alone, one should not vote for.  this withdrawal agreement.  They should not vote for that withdrawal agreement.

In my exchanges with the Shadow Secretary of State for DEXU, I would want to know why anyone would want to undermine the repeal of the 1972 Act, which is the law of the land, which is actually contained in Section 1 of the Withdrawal Act itself.  And I'd also like people to be honest enough, those who wish to rejoin the European Union, and I include my right honourable friend, a learned member for Beaconsfield, who wants to rejoin the European Union, Why on earth would anyone want to rejoin this European Union, when the whole of the European Union itself is in complete and total erosion, and at the same time, they're voting with their feet.  They're voting with their feet.  They are voting with their feet.  in so many countries, including Italy.  So, in a nutshell, I'd simply say I do think that the withdrawal agreement is deeply, deeply flawed, and we ought to vote against it.  And I also believe that the decision at the moment, which, as I understand it, has not been concluded, is that those amendments are going to be withdrawn.
But I look forward to the member for me.  please call your MP and state that clearly.
So, in a nutshell, I'd simply say I do think that the withdrawal agreement is deeply, deeply flawed and we ought to vote against it.

And I also believe that the decision at the moment, which as I understand it, has not been concluded, is that those amendments are going to be withdrawn.  But I look forward to a better campaign.  Right.  This is Catania Alvin saying cheerio.  God bless and have a wonderful day.  And if you're in England, phone your MP.  And if you're in America, send that Mullah Lyndon LaRouche information out as far and wide as you can.  God bless everyone.  Stay safe.  Stay well.
